organizations: Plastics Engineering Company Center for Engineering Studies
title: UW-S engineering building officially opened
text:
UW-S engineering building officially opened Kali Thiel , Sheboygan Press Media 8:36 a.m. CDT October 22, 2015 Buy Photo University of Wisconsin-Sheboygan student Ian Fahres gives a demonstration of a wind tunnel Thursday, Oct. 1, during the dedication ceremony for the new Plastics Engineering Company Center for Engineering Studies on the UW-Sheboygan campus. (Photo: Kali Thiel/Sheboygan Press Media) Buy Photo 1 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
When Tim Schneider made the decision eight years ago to pursue an engineering degree in order to advance his career, he knew being a college student wouldn't be the only commitment on his plate. 
The 29-year-old, who lives in Kewaskum, is also a husband and father of three, with one more on the way, and he maintains a full-time job as an electrical technician for Kohler Co. 
That's why, upon first entering the newly opened engineering building on the University of Wisconsin-Sheboygan campus, Schneider immediately took note of the increase in lab stations, which ultimately will mean no wait time for the non-traditional student trying to maximize his time. 
"As a working, adult student, when you go to lab, you want to be working on the lab, not standing around waiting for the equipment," Schneider said. "With the old lab, we’d often be standing there waiting for someone else to finish up so we could work on ours. I think there’s probably at least a dozen stations in this new lab, so that alone is just really nice.” 
The new building, called the Plastics Engineering Company Center for Engineering Studies, officially opened this semester to students in UW-Sheboygan's collaborative engineering program with the University of Wisconsin-Platteville. A dedication ceremony for the building was held Thursday, Oct. 1. 
The 7,200-square-foot building, which cost some $1.4 million, provides mechanical and electrical engineering labs, a projects lab, classroom space, group study areas and three offices. It also boasts new, advanced equipment including a wind tunnel, pump test trainer, flow meter loop and an electrical dynometer. 
Students now have access to state-of-the-art equipment instead of making do with equipment like the apparatus Steve Gehling, a lecturer for the program, built to teach students properties of various metals and plastics. 
"I built something in my garage that wasn't so good," Gehling said. "We learned, but it's not as nice as having the proper equipment." Buy Photo 
University of Wisconsin-Sheboygan student Martha Steffen explains how a fluid circuit demonstrator works Thursday, Oct. 1, during the dedication ceremony for the new Plastics Engineering Company Center for Engineering Studies on the UW-Sheboygan campus. (Photo: Kali Thiel/Sheboygan Press Media) 
UW-Sheboygan Dean and CEO Jackie Joseph-Silverstein says the building provides "a home" for students in one of the school's fastest-growing programs. 
Nearly 70 UW-Sheboygan students currently list engineering as a major, and approximately 20 more have already matriculated into the UW-Platteville program, according to a news release from the school. 
Perhaps most importantly, the building supports students in an in-demand field, providing a close-to-home learning opportunity for those already living in the area — and those whom many local employers say they hope will stay in the area. 
"(Engineering) is a very important skill set, but there's not enough of them," Gehling said. "If there's not enough of them, recruiting becomes an issue to move people from their families to our area. …From a business' point of view, this opens up the doors to many dozens of people right here in our community."
